text: fears of a radiation leak are real and
officials have been warning residents to
evacuate or stay indoors I'm Denise
Grady a reporter at The New York Times
and we're looking today at what the
possible health effects are in Japan
from the radiation releases from the
reactors so far the big difference here
between Japan and Chernobyl is that
there has not been a meltdown or an
explosion of a containment vessel that
has blown out all of the contents into
the atmosphere so the level of
contamination so far anyway is way way
smaller and even if there was a higher
level of contamination in Japan this
situation doesn't have to turn into
another Chernobyl because they have been
out ahead of it they have evacuated
people from the area that they are
telling people to take potassium iodide
they're distributing it we know enough
now that people in areas like this
should not be eating local produce or
drinking milk from local cows and that
was the great tragedy at Chernobyl
children drank milk from local cows it
was laced full of radioactive iodine
that went to the thyroid gland and
caused at least 6,000 cases of thyroid
cancer and the more are expected there
were colossal mistakes of many kinds at
Chernobyl but one thing that they did
right in the end was the cleanup and
they took a very interesting approach
that which was they brought in 600,000
people who were called liquidators to
help the cleanup each one of them stayed
for a very short time so you took the
exposure and you spread it out over a
whole lot of people so you had a lot of
people that just got a little bit of
exposure of course they were not exactly
volunteers but this was how it was done
you
